revision.text:
{{for|events in medicine in the 21st century|21st century#Medicine}} '''21st Century Medicine''' (21CM) is a California cryobiological research company which has as its primary focus the development of [[Perfusion|perfusates]] and [[Guideline (medical)|protocols]] for [[Life|viable]] long-term [[cryopreservation]] of human [[organ (anatomy)|organs]], [[Biological tissue|tissue]]s and [[Cell (biology)|cell]]s at [[cryogenic]] [[temperature]]s (temperatures below −100 °C) through the use of [[Glass transition|vitrification]]. 21CM was founded in 1993.
[[Greg Fahy|Dr. Gregory M. Fahy]], who pioneered the use of [[vitrification]] in [[reproductive biology|reproductive]] [[cryopreservation]],<ref>{{cite book |author1=Michael J. Taylor |author2=Ying C. Song |author3=Kelvin G.M. Brockbank | title = Vitrification in Tissue Preservation: New Developments In: ''Life in the Frozen State'' (B.J. Fuller, N. Lane, and E.E. Benson, Eds.) | publisher = [[CRC Press]] | pages = 603–641 | year = 2004 | isbn = 0-415-24700-4 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |author1=Fahy, G.M. |author2=Hirsh, A. | title = Prospects for Organ Preservation by Vitrification. In: ''Organ Preservation, Basic and Applied Aspects'' (D.E. Pegg, I.A. Jacobsen and N.A. Halasz, Eds.) | publisher = [[Springer Science+Business Media|Springer]] | pages = 399–404 | year = 1982 | isbn = 0-85200-418-4 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Fahy GM, MacFarlane DR, Angell CA, Meryman HT | title=Vitrification as an approach to cryopreservation | journal=Cryobiology | volume=21 | issue=4 | year=1984 | pages=407–426 | id= | pmid=6467964 | doi=10.1016/0011-2240(84)90079-8}}</ref><ref name="Nature">{{cite journal |vauthors=Rall WF, Fahy GM | title=Ice-free cryopreservation of mouse embryos at -196 degrees C by vitrification | journal=[[Nature (journal)|Nature]] | volume=313 | issue=6003 | year=1985 | pages=573–575 | id= | pmid=3969158 | doi=10.1038/313573a0}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | author=Fahy GM | title=Vitrification: a new approach to organ cryopreservation| journal=PROGRESS IN CLINICAL AND BIOLOGICAL RESEARCH | volume=224 | year=1986 | pages=305–335 | id= | pmid=3540994}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | last = Fahy | first = Gregory M. | title = Vitrification versus Freezing of Organs | work = [[Science (journal)|Science]] E-Letter responses | publisher = [[American Association for the Advancement of Science]] | date = May 16, 2002 | url = http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/eletters/296/5568/655d | accessdate = 2010-10-22 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |author1=Fahy, G.M. |author2=Rall, W.F | title = Vitrification: An overview. In: ''Vitrification in Assisted Reproduction: A User's Manual and Troubleshooting Guide'' (J. Liebermann and M.J. Tucker, Eds) | publisher = Informa Healthcare | year = 2007 | isbn = 0-415-40882-2 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |author1=Mullen, S.F. |author2=Fahy, G.M | title = Fundamental aspects of vitrification as a method of reproductive cell, tissue, and organ cryopreservation. In: ''Principles & Practice of Fertility Preservation'' (Donnez, J., and Kim, S.S., Eds.) | publisher = [[Cambridge University Press]] | date = February 28, 2011 | isbn = 0-521-19695-7 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | title=Cryopreservation of embryos | journal=[[The Lancet]] | volume=1 | issue=8430 | year=1985 | pages=678 | id= | pmid=2858625 | doi=10.1016/s0140-6736(85)91336-4}}</ref> serves on the company’s [[Board of Directors]] and prioritizes, develops and directs the company’s research activities. He also manages all extramural collaborative research projects with universities, industry and research institutions to create specific products and services.
The company holds a number of [[patent]]s, most notably for [[cryoprotectant]] mixtures that greatly reduce [[ice]] formation while minimizing cryoprotectant [[Toxin|toxic]]ity, as well as for synthetic ice-blockers that inexpensively simulate the [[antifreeze protein]] found in [[arctic]] [[organism]]s. Their website lists [[peer-reviewed]] [[scientific journal|journal]] publications based on research conducted in their laboratories.<ref name="Publications">{{cite web | title = 21CM Publications | url = http://www.21cm.com/abstracts.jsp | accessdate = 2006-11-08 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20061018161035/http://www.21cm.com/abstracts.jsp| archivedate= 18 October 2006 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> In 2004 21CM received a $900,000 grant from the [[National Institutes of Health|U.S. National Institutes of Health]] (NIH) to study a preservation solution developed by the [[University of Rochester]] in New York for extending simple cold storage time of human hearts removed for [[Organ transplant|transplant]].<ref name="Grant">{{cite web | title = NIH grant to be used for heart preservation research | publisher = Business Wire | date = October 31, 2004 | url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/21st+Century+Medicine+Receives+NIH+Grant+to+Pursue+Heart+Preservation.-a0122727566 | accessdate = 2012-05-02 }}</ref>
At the July 2005 annual conference of the Society for [[Cryobiology]], 21st Century Medicine announced the vitrification of a [[rabbit]] [[kidney]] to -135 °C with their [[patent|proprietary]] vitrification mixture. The kidney was successfully transplanted upon rewarming to a rabbit, the rabbit being euthanized on the 48th day for histological follow-up.<ref name="Kidney">{{cite web|title=Plenary Session: Fundamentals of Biopreservation |work=CRYO 2005 Scientific Program |publisher=Society for Cryobiology |date=July 24, 2005 |url=http://www.me.umn.edu/events/cryo2005/program.html |accessdate=2006-11-08 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060830143259/http://www.me.umn.edu/events/cryo2005/program.html |archivedate=2006-08-30 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Fahy GM, Wowk B, Pagotan R, Chang A, Phan J, Thomson B, Phan L | title=Physical and biological aspects of renal vitrification | journal=ORGANOGENESIS | issue=3 | year=2009 | pages=167–175 | doi = 10.4161/org.5.3.9974 | id= | pmid=20046680 | volume=5 | quote=After ensuring that the animal appeared capable of living indefinitely using the vitrified kidney as the sole renal support, it was euthanized for histological follow-up on day 48. | pmc=2781097}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Cryobiology]] * [[Cryopreservation]] * [[Biobank]] * [[Tissue Engineering]] * [[Organ Transplantation]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.21cm.com 21st Century Medicine ]
{{Cryonics}}
[[Category:Cryobiology]] [[Category:Cryogenics]]

revision.text:
An '''anticyclonic tornado''' is a [[tornado]] which rotates in a [[clockwise]] direction in the [[Northern Hemisphere]] and a [[counterclockwise]] direction in the [[Southern Hemisphere]]. The term is a naming convention denoting the anomaly from normal rotation which is [[cyclonic]] in upwards of 98 percent of tornadoes. Many [[Anticyclone|anticyclonic]] tornadoes are smaller and weaker than cyclonic tornadoes, forming from a different process. [[File:Bigspringanticyclonictornado.jpg|thumb|An anticyclonic tornado near [[Big Spring, Texas]] on May 22, 2016 captured by [[Storm chasing|storm chaser]] Aaron Jayjack.]]
==Formation== Most strong tornadoes form in the [[inflow (meteorology)|inflow]] and updraft area bordering the [[updraft]]-[[downdraft]] interface (which is also near the [[mesoscale meteorology|mesoscale]] "triple point") zone of [[supercell]] [[thunderstorm]]s. The thunderstorm itself is rotating, with a rotating updraft known as a [[mesocyclone]], and then a smaller area of rotation at lower altitude the [[tornadocyclone]] (or [[low-level mesocyclone]]) which produces or enables the smaller rotation that is a tornado. All of these may be quasi-vertically aligned continuing from the ground to the mid-upper levels of the storm. All of these [[cyclone]]s and scaling all the way up to large [[extratropical cyclone|extratropical]] ([[low-pressure system]]s) and [[tropical cyclone]]s rotate cyclonically. Rotation in these [[synoptic scale]] systems stems partly from the [[Coriolis effect]], but thunderstorms and tornadoes are too small to be significantly affected. The common property here is an area of lower pressure, thus surrounding air flows into the area of less dense air forming [[cyclonic rotation]]. The rotation of the thunderstorm itself is induced mostly by vertical [[wind shear]].
Various processes can produce an anticyclonic tornado. Most often they are [[satellite tornado]]es of larger tornadoes which are directly associated with the tornadocyclone and mesocyclone. Occasionally anticyclonic tornadoes occur as an anticyclonic companion ([[mesoanticyclone]]) to a mesocyclone within a single storm. Anticyclonic tornadoes can occur as the primary tornado with a mesocyclone and under a [[rotating wall cloud]]. Also, anticyclonic supercells (with mesoanticyclone), which usually are storms that split and move to the left of the parent storm motion, though very rarely spawning tornadoes, spawn anticyclonic tornadoes. There is an increased incidence of anticyclonic tornadoes associated with tropical cyclones, and [[mesovortices]] within [[bow echo]]es may spawn anticyclonic tornadoes.<ref>{{cite book|last=Stull|first=Roland B.|title=Meteorology for Scientists and Engineers|year=2000|publisher=Thomson Learning|isbn=9780534372149|edition=2nd}}</ref>
The first anticyclonic tornado associated with a mesoanticyclone was spotted on [[NEXRAD|WSR-88D]] weather radar in Sunnyvale, California May 4, 1998. The tornado was an F-2 on the [[Fujita Scale]].<ref name=":0">{{cite journal|last=Monteverdi|first=John P.|author2=Blier, Warren|author3= Stumpf, Greg|author4= Pi, Wilfred|author5= Anderson, Karl|title=First WSR-88D Documentation of an Anticyclonic Supercell with Anticyclonic Tornadoes: The Sunnyvale–Los Altos, California, Tornadoes of 4 May 1998|journal=Monthly Weather Review|date=November 2001|volume=129|issue=11|pages=2805–2814|doi=10.1175/1520-0493(2001)129<2805:FWDOAA>2.0.CO;2|url=http://journals.ametsoc.org/doi/abs/10.1175/1520-0493%282001%29129%3C2805%3AFWDOAA%3E2.0.CO%3B2|bibcode = 2001MWRv..129.2805M }}</ref>
== See also == * [[Vortex]] * [[Vorticity]] * [[Pressure gradient force]] (PGF) * [[Rossby number]] * [[Anticyclonic storm]]
== References == {{reflist|2}}
== External links == * [http://www.nssl.noaa.gov/divisions/warning/swat/Cases/980504/case.html Tornadic Meso-anticyclonic supercell in Sunnyvale California] ([[National Severe Storms Laboratory|NSSL]]) * {{cite journal | last = Bunkers | first = Matthew J. |author2=John W. Stoppkotte |date= January 2007 | title = Documentation of a Rare Tornadic Left-Moving Supercell | journal = [[Electronic Journal of Severe Storms Meteorology]] | volume = 2 | issue = 2 | pages = 1–22 | doi = | url = http://www.ejssm.org/ojs/index.php/ejssm/article/view/14 }}
[[Category:Anticyclones]] [[Category:Tornado]]

revision.text:
{{good article}} [[File:DBP 1991 1490-R.JPG|thumb|German postage stamp from 1991, commemorating 750 years of the apothecary profession]] The '''apothecaries' system''' or '''apothecaries' weights and measures''' is a historical system of [[mass]] and [[volume]] units that were used by [[physician]]s and [[apothecary|apothecaries]] for medical recipes, and also sometimes by scientists."Medicinal-Gewicht, Apotheker-Gewicht ist dasjenige Gewicht, nach welchem Aerzte und Apotheker die Quantitäten der Arzneimittel bestimmen. Nur an wenigen Orten werden beide Arten der Gewichte unterschieden und Medicinalgewicht bei dem Einkauf der Arzneiwaaren im Großen von dem Apothekergewicht bei der Anfertigung und dem Einzel-Verkauf in den Apotheken getrennt. In diesem Fall ist das Medicinalgewicht dem gewöhnlichen Landesgewicht beinahe oder völlig gleich und das Pfund wird dann in 16 Unzen getheilt. Bei dem eigentlichen Apothekergewicht aber nimmt man nur einen Theil des Landesgewichts und theilt dieses Pfund in 12 Unzen oder 96 Drachmen oder 288 Scrupel oder 5760 Gran oder 7452 Aß." {{cite book | last=Krüger | first=J.F. | title=Vollständiges Handbuch der Münzen, Maße und Gewichte aller Länder der Erde | location=Quedlinburg und Leipzig | year=1830 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iro2AAAAMAAJ&printsec=titlepage#PPA186,M1 | page=186}}{{cite book | title=The elements of experimental chemistry | last=Henry | first=William | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TFA6AAAAMAAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=editions:LCCN49038747#PPA493,M1 | edition=11th | volume=Vol. II | location=Philadelphia | year=1831 | page=493 }}"Die deutschen Schriftsteller bedienen sich bei dem Mangel allgemeiner deutscher Maße meistens der Altfranzösischen, des Apothekergewichts, der metrischen Maße und Gewichte, die preußischen am allgemeinsten, die Baiern nicht selten der in ihren Staaten eingeführten." {{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fO8EAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA1359#PPA1359,M1 | title=Physikalisches Wörterbuch | last=Gehler | first=J.S.T. | year=1836 | location=Leipzig | volume=Vol. VI, Part 2 |page=1359|display-authors=etal}} The English version of the system is closely related to the English [[troy weight|troy]] system of weights, the [[Pound (mass)|pound]] and [[grain (mass)|grain]] being exactly the same in both.The [[avoirdupois]] pound, on the other hand, is defined as 7000 grains. It is subdivided into 16 (avoirdupois) ounces, or 256 (avoirdupois) drachms. These ounces and drachms are not integer multiples of a grain. It divides a pound into 12 ounces, an ounce into 8 [[Dram (unit)|drachms]], and a drachm into 3 [[scruple (unit)|scruples]] or 60 grains. This exact form of the system was used in the United Kingdom; in some of its former colonies it survived well into the 20th century."Apothecaries Weights were the weights which Pharmaceutical Chemists (or Pharmacists) [in Australia] used exclusively until the late 1960's." {{cite web | url=http://home.iprimus.com.au/davecoates/ | title=Apothecaries Weights }} "To those Pharmacists who were in practice before the 1960's, Apothecaries Weights were old friends." {{cite journal | last=Coates | first=David | title=The Scruples of a Chemist | journal=Pharmacy History Australia |date=July 1998 | url=http://home.iprimus.com.au/davecoates/article1.html }}"Although fast becoming obsolete, the apothecary system for weighing and calculating pharmaceutical preparations is still used and must be taken into consideration." {{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Sj1xndpFqzYC&pg=PP242 | title=Hospital corpsman – Nonresident training course | year=2000 | author=US Navy | pages=6–10–6–16 | publisher=DIANE Publishing | isbn=1-4289-2660-7 }} The apothecaries' system of measures is a similar system of [[volume]] units based on the fluid ounce. For a long time, medical recipes were written in [[Latin language|Latin]], often using special symbols to denote weights and measures. The use of different measure and weight systems depending on the purpose was an almost universal phenomenon in Europe between the decline of the [[Roman Empire]] and [[metrication]]."An acre is not an acre, nor a bushel a bushel, if you travel but ten miles. A pound is not a pound, if you go from a goldsmith to a grocer; nor a gallon a gallon, if you go from the alehouse to the tavern. What purpose does this variety serve, or what necessity is there, which the difference of price would not better answer and supply?" {{cite book | last=Fleetwood | first=William | location=Oxford | year=1854 | title=The Works | volume=Vol. III | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=p4INAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA61 | page=61}} This was connected with international commerce, especially with the need to use the standards of the target market and to compensate for a common weighing practice that caused a difference between actual and nominal weight.{{cite journal | url=http://www.allbusiness.com/north-america/canada/496291-1.html | last=Connor | first=R.D. | title=The evolution of weighing | journal=Canadian Chemical News | year=1995 }}{{cite book | last=Connor | first=R.D. |author2=Simpson, A.D.C. | title=Weights and Measures in Scotland | location=East Linton | year=2004 | isbn=978-1-901663-88-4 | publisher=NMSE }} In the 19th century, most European countries or cities still had at least a "commercial" or "civil" system (such as the English [[avoirdupois]] system) for general trading, and a second system (such as the [[troy weight|troy]] system) for precious metals such as gold and silver."In most countries there are two kinds of Weights, one for the precious Metals, and the other for Merchandize, as the Troy and Avoirdupois Weights in England. {{cite book | last=Kelly | first=Patrick | title=The universal cambist, and commercial instructor | volume=Vol. I | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vUwOAAAAQAAJ&printsec=frontcover#PPP21,M1 | location=London | year=1811 | page=xi }} The system for precious metals was usually divided in a different way from the commercial system, often using special units such as the [[Carat (unit)|carat]]. More significantly, it was often based on different weight standards. The apothecaries' system often used the same ounces as the precious metals system, although even then the number of ounces in a pound could be different. The apothecaries' pound was divided into its own special units, which were inherited (via influential treatises of Greek physicians such as [[Pedanius Dioscorides|Dioscorides]] and [[Galen]], 1st and 2nd century) from the general-purpose weight system of the Romans. Where the apothecaries' weights and the normal commercial weights were different, it was not always clear which of the two systems was used in trade between merchants and apothecaries, or by which system apothecaries weighed medicine when they actually sold it.{{cite journal|journal=Apothecary's Cabinet |year=2006 |publisher=American Institute of the History of Pharmacy |last=Hasegawa |first=G.R. |title=Preparing and dispensing descriptions during the Civil War Era |url=http://www.pharmacy.wisc.edu/aihp/AC/AC10.pdf |format= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070809121753/http://www.pharmacy.wisc.edu/aihp/AC/AC10.pdf |archivedate=August 9, 2007 }}In 1850, an attempt was made in Ireland to solve this problem: "In relation to the weights and measures, a great innovation has been made, which, however, the College feels confident will receive the sanction of the public and the profession. [...] In the formularies, however, [of the Edinburgh Pharmacopœia], the Troy pound, with its well-known submultiples, has been retained, whereas it is now rejected by the Irish College, and its place supplied by the avoirdupois pound, the avoirdupois ounce being, like the Troy ounce, subdivided into eight drachms, and each of these, like the Troy drachm, into three scruples. [...] At present the two systems are in use with the apothecary, for his purchases are made in avoirdupois, and his sales generally, though not always, in Troy weight." {{cite book | title=The Pharmacopœia of the King and Queen's College of Physicians in Ireland | year=1850 | author=Royal College of Physicians in Ireland | location=Dublin | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=V-5NAAAAMAAJ&pg=PR22#PPR22,M1 | page=xxii }} See also [https://books.google.com/books?id=V-5NAAAAMAAJ&pg=PR46#PPR46,M1 p. xlvi], and a [https://books.google.com/books?id=UOcEAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA350 review of the work]. In old merchants' handbooks the former system is sometimes referred to as the '''pharmaceutical system''', and distinguished from the apothecaries' system."Im Königreich der Niederlande ist das Medicinal-Gewicht im Großen und das eigentliche Apotheker-Gewicht verschieden. Bei dem erstern gehören 8 Drachmen zu einer Once (Unze) und 128 zu einem Medicinal-Pond; die Drachme wird wie in Deutschland in 3 Scrupel oder 60 Grän getheilt. In dem eigentlichen Apotheker-Gewicht gehören auch 8 Drachemn zu einer Unze, aber nur 96 Drachmen zu einem Pond. Die Drachme selbst ist in beiden Gewichtsarten gleich [...]." {{cite book | last=Krüger | first=J.F. | title=Vollständiges Handbuch der Münzen, Maße und Gewichte aller Länder der Erde | location=Quedlinburg und Leipzig | year=1830 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iro2AAAAMAAJ&printsec=titlepage#PPA65,M1 | page=65}}E.g. in [[Copenhagen]] at some time the apothecaries' system was the Prussian one, while the pharmaceutical system was the Danish commercial system. "Das Apothekergewicht ist dem unter Berlin bemerkten gleich; im Großen aber werden Medicinalartikel nach Dän. Handelsgewicht verkauft." {{cite book | last=Bock | first=J.H.D. |author2=Crüger, Carl | title=Nelkenbrecher's allgemeines Taschenbuch der Münz-, Maß- und Gewichtskunde für Banquiers und Kaufleute | edition=14th | location=Berlin | year=1828 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=M7o2AAAAMAAJ&pg=PA188 | page=188 }} __TOC__ ==English-speaking countries== {{See also|Imperial units|United States customary units}} The traditional English apothecaries' system of weights is as shown in the table, the pound, ounce and grain being identical to the [[troy pound]], ounce and grain. In the United Kingdom, a reform in 1826 made the troy pound the primary weight unit (a role in which it was superseded half a century later by the Avoirdupois pound), but this had no effect on apothecaries' weights. However, the Medicinals Act of 1858 completely abolished the apothecaries' system in favour of the standard Avoirdupois system. The confusing variety of definitions and conversions for pounds and ounces is covered elsewhere in a [[:Template:English pounds|table of pound definitions]]. In the United States, the apothecaries' system remained official until it was abolished in 1971 in favour of the metric system. From the pound down to the scruple, the English apothecaries' system was a subset of the [[#Roman weight system|Roman weight system]] except that the troy pound and its subdivisions were slightly heavier than the Roman pound and its subdivisions. Similar systems were used all over Europe, but with considerable local variation described below under [[#Variants|Variants]].{{cite book | last=Zupko | first=Ronald Edward | authorlink=Ronald Edward Zupko | location=Maddison | year=1977 | title=British Weights & Measures: A History from Antiquity to the Seventeenth Century |publisher= The University of Wisconsin Press | isbn= 0-299-07340-8 | page=5 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pWUgAQAAIAAJ}} {{clear}} {| align="center" | {|class="wikitable IPA" |+ British Apothecaries' weights and conversions
(pre-imperial-based version, until 1864){{cite book |title=London Pharmacopoeia, 1796 |year=1796 |url=https://archive.org/stream/b21442447#page/2/mode/2up/ | accessdate=2016-09-22}} ! Weight
(abbreviation) !! pound
(℔, ″̶) !! ounce
(℥) !! dram
(drachm)
(ʒ)!! scruple
(℈) !! grain
(gr) |- align="right" |rowspan="4"| || 1 ℔ || 12 ℥|| 96 ʒ || 288 ℈|| 5,760 gr |- align="right" || ||1 ℥ || 8 ʒ || 24 ℈|| 480 gr |- align="right" || || ||1 ʒ|| 3 ℈|| 60 gr |- align="right" || || || || 1 ℈ || 20 gr |- align="center" ! metric equivalent ||373 g || 31.1 g || 3.89 g || 1.296 g || 64.8 mg |} | {|class="wikitable IPA" |+ British Apothecaries' weights and conversions (post-imperial-based version, 1864–1971){{cite book |title=British Pharmacopoeia, 1864 |year=1864 |url=https://archive.org/stream/b20405558#page/n27/mode/2up/ | accessdate=2016-09-22}} ! Weight
(abbreviation) !! pound
(lb) !! ounce
(oz) !! grain
(gr) |- align="right" |rowspan="2"| || 1 lb || 16 oz|| 7,000 gr |- align="right" || ||1 oz || 437.5 gr |- align="center" ! metric equivalent || || || |} |} The English-speaking countries also used a system of units of fluid measure, or in modern terminology [[volume]] units, based on the apothecaries' system. A volume of liquid that was approximately that of an [[apothecaries' ounce]] of water was called a fluid ounce, and was divided into fluid drachms and sometimes also fluid scruples. The analogue of the grain was called a [[minim (unit)|minim]]. The [[imperial unit|imperial]] and [[United States customary units|US]] systems differ in the size of the basic unit (the [[gallon]] or the [[pint]], one gallon being equal to eight pints), and in the number of fluid ounces per pint. Apothecaries' systems for volumes were internationally much less common than those for weights.E.g. a German handbook of medicine prescription from 1835 when describing the English system mentioned that no such system was in current use in Germany: "Von Maassen ist in Deutschland gegenwärtig [...] fast nur noch das Quart [...] gebräuchlich." {{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rWcOAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA99 | last=Phoebus | first=P. | title=Handbuch der Arzneiverordnungslehre | year=1836 | location=Berlin | volume=Vol. I | page=99}} Before introduction of the imperial units in the UK, all apothecaries' measures were based on the [[wine gallon]], which survived in the US under the name ''liquid gallon'' or ''wet gallon''.{{cite book | last=Brande | first=W.T. | title=A manual of chemistry | year=1830 | volume=Vol. I | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=u79wbv8_TaEC&pg=RA1-PA490 | page=490 }} The wine gallon was abolished in Britain in 1826, and this system was replaced by a new one based on the newly introduced imperial gallon.{{cite book | last=Skinner | first=F.G. | location=London | year=1967 | title=Weights and Measures: their ancient origins and their development in Great Britain up to AD 1855 | publisher = Her Majesty's Stationery Office | pages=106–109.}} Since the imperial gallon is 20% more than the liquid gallon, the same is true for the imperial pint in relation to the liquid pint. This explains why the number of fluid ounces per gallon had to be adjusted in the new system so that the fluid ounce was not changed too much by the reform. Even so, the modern UK fluid ounce is 4% ''less'' than the US fluid ounce, and the same is true for the smaller units. For some years both systems were used concurrently in the UK.{{cite journal | year=1853 | journal=Medical Times | title=Weights and Measures | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uxsCAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA312 }} {{clear}} {| align="center" | {|class="wikitable IPA" |+ Measures: US{{cite book |title=The Parmacopeia of the United States of America, Ninth Decennial Revision|year=1916 |url=https://archive.org/stream/pharmacopeiaofun09unit#page/n53/mode/2up | accessdate=2016-09-22}} (& UK pre-1864) ! pint !! fl ounce !! fl dram !! fl scruple !! minim |- style="text-align:right; white-space:nowrap;" | 1 pt || 16 ƒ℥ || 128 ƒʒ || 384 ƒ℈ || 7,680 {{emoji presentation|♏|text}} |- align="right" | || 1 ƒ℥ || 8 ƒʒ || 24 ƒ℈ || 480 {{emoji presentation|♏|text}} |- align="right" | || || 1 ƒʒ || 3 ƒ℈ || 60 {{emoji presentation|♏|text}} |- align="right" | || || || 1 ƒ℈ || 20 {{emoji presentation|♏|text}} |- style="text-align:right; white-space:nowrap;" ! Saunders |location=Philadelphia |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XesRAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA582#v=onepage&f=false |lccn=18001726 |postscript=.}}{{rp|582}} {{Citation |last=Barr |first=William Miller |year=1918 |title=Industrial engineering: a handbook of useful information for managers, engineers, superintendents, designers, draftsmen and other engaged in constructive work, Part 1 |publisher=W.M. Barr Company |location=New York City |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aK9XAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA43#v=onepage&f=false |lccn=18023408 |postscript=.}}{{rp|43}} or ''[[wikt:octarius#Latin|octarius]]'' {{Citation |last=Thornton |first=Edward Quin |year=1911 |title=A Manual of Materia Medica for Medical Students |publisher=Lea and Febiger |location=Philadelphia |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=K5A0AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA60#v=onepage&f=false |lccn=15021277 |postscript=.}}{{rp|60}} {{Citation |editor-last=Hare |editor-first=Hobart Amory |editor-last2=Chrystie |editor-first2=Walter |year=1891 |title=A System of Practical Therapeutics |publisher=Lea Brothers and Company |location=Philadelphia |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5vE0AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA57#v=onepage&f=false |lccn=07005735 |postscript=.}}{{rp|57}} {{Citation |last=Dunglison |first=Robley |year=1844 |title=The Medical Student; Or, Aids to the Study of Medicine |publisher=Lea and Blanchard |location=Philadelphia |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5q0-AAAAYAAJ&pg=PA145#v=onepage&f=false |postscript=.}}{{rp|145}} ({{frac|1|8}} ''congius'') |} |} There were also commonly used, but unofficial divisions of the Apothecaries' system, consisting of:{{cite book|author=Sir Robert Christison|title=A dispensatory, or commentary on the pharmacopoeias of Great Britain: comprising the natural history, description, chemistry, pharmacy, actions, uses, and doses of the articles of the materia medica|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zpg-AAAAYAAJ&pg=PR38&dq=%22dessert+spoon&hl=en&sa=X&ei=MirxTvvgL6rRiAKg_IC9Dg&ved=0CEkQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22dessert%20spoon%22&f=false|accessdate=20 December 2011|year=1842|publisher=Black|page=38}} *glass-tumbler 8 fl oz *breakfast-cup about 8 fl oz *tea-cup 5 fl oz *wine-glass 2 fl oz *table-spoon 1/2 fl oz *dessert-spoon 2 fl dr (same as {{frac|4}} fl oz) *tea-spoon 1 fl dr (same as {{frac|8}} fl oz) In the US, the similar measures in use were once *Tumblerful — ƒ℥ viii (240 mL) *Teacupful — ƒ℥ iv (120 mL) *Wineglassful — ƒ℥ ij (60 mL) *Tablespoonful— ƒ℥ ss (20 mL) (once codified in the U.S.P. IX) *Desertspoonful— ƒʒ ij (10 mL)(once codified in the U.S.P. IX) *Teaspoonful — ƒʒ j (5 mL)(once codified in the U.S.P. IX) The cited book states, "In almost all cases the modern teacups, tablespoons, dessertspoons, and teaspoons, after careful test by the author, were found to average 25 per cent. greater capacity than the theoretical quantities given above, and thus the use of accurately graduated medicine glasses, which may be had now at a trifling cost, should be insisted upon."{{cite book|title=Remington's Pharmaceutical Sciences, Volume 6 |date=|location=|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3KVGAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA45|accessdate=}} Apothecaries' measures eventually fell out of use in the UK and were officially abolished in 1971. In the US, they are still occasionally used, for example with prescribed medicine being sold in four ounce (℥ iv) bottles.In 2002, the FDA recalled medicine sold in four ounce bottles because the measuring cup enclosed only had metric units. [http://www.fda.gov/bbs/topics/enforce/2002/ENF00775.html] ==Medical recipes== Until around 1900, medical recipes and most European [[pharmacopoeia]]s were written in Latin. Here is a typical example from the middle of the 19th century.{{cite book | last=Ellis | first=Benjamin | year=1854 | edition=10th | title=Medical Formulary | location=Philadelphia | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AEgVrVQl9McC&pg=PA69 }} {|style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto; background: #ffff99" |colspan=2|'''''Infusion of Dandelion, &c.''''' |- |℞||Infusi Taraxaci, f℥iv.|| ||4 fluid ounces of [[Taraxacum officinale|dandelion]] [[infusion]] |- | ||Extracti Taraxaci, fʒij.|| ||2 fluid drachms of dandelion [[extract]] |- | ||Sodæ Carbonatis, ʒss.|| ||{{frac|1|2}} drachm of [[sodium carbonate]] |- | ||Potassæ Tartratis, ʒiij.|| ||3 drachms of [[potassium tartrate]] |- | ||Tincturæ Rhei, fʒiij.|| ||3 fluid drachms of [[rhubarb]] [[tincture]] |- | ||———— Hyoscyami, gtt. xx.|| ||20 dropsA drop was approximately 1 minim. {{cite encyclopedia | encyclopedia=A cyclopaedia of six thousand practical receipts | last=Cooley | first=A.J. | year=1850 | title=Weights |page=8 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=f38EAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA8 }} of [[hyoscyamus niger|henbane]] tincture |- |colspan=2|Fiat mistura. ''Signa.''—One third part to be taken
three times a day. In dropsical and visceral affections.|| ||Make mixture. ''Write:'' "One third part to be taken
three times a day. In dropsical and visceral affections." |} The use of Latin ensured that the recipes could be read by an international audience. There was a technical reason why ''3 ʒ'' was written ''ʒiij,'' and ''{{frac|1|2}} ʒ'' as ''ʒss'': Writing ''iii'' as ''iij'' would prevent tampering with or misinterpretation of a number after it is written. The letters "ss" are an abbreviation for the Latin "semis" meaning "half", which were sometimes written with a [[Sharp S|ß]]. In Apothecaries' Latin, numbers were generally written in Roman numerals, immediately following the symbol. Since only the units of the apothecaries' system were used in this way, this made it clear that the civil weight system was not meant."As this abbreviation [referring to ''Lb.''] is used to represent both the avoirdupois, and troy or apothecaries' pound, it is necessary to observe, that the ''former'' is indicated when this sign is ''preceded'' by ''Arabic figures''; and the ''latter'', when it is followed by Roman numerals." {{cite encyclopedia | encyclopedia=A cyclopaedia of six thousand practical receipts | last=Cooley | first=A.J. | year=1850 | title=Weights |page=560 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=f38EAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA561 }} ==Variants== ===Diversity of local standards=== {|class="wikitable" align="left" style="margin:0 1em 0 0" |+ Variation in standards for apothecaries' weights ! 12 ounces || 1 ounce || Standard |- | 300 g || 25 g || Venice |- | 325 g || 27 g || [[Roman Empire]] |- | 340 g || 28 g || Modern Rome |- | 345 g || 29 g || Iberian peninsula |- | 350 g || 29 g || Prussia |- | 360 g || 30 g || Nuremberg |- | 370 g || 31 g || Troy |- | 420 g || 35 g || Habsburg monarchy |} The basic form of the apothecaries' system is essentially a subset of the Roman weight system. An apothecaries' pound normally consisted of 12 ounces. (In France this was changed to 16 ounces, and in Spain the customary unit was the ''marco'', a [[mark (mass)|mark]] of 8 ounces.) In the south of Europe and in France, the scruple was generally divided into 24 grains, so that one ounce consisted of 576 grains. Nevertheless, the subdivision of an ounce was somewhat more uniform than that of a pound, and a common feature of all variants is that 12 ounces are roughly 100 drachms (96–128 drachms) and a grain is roughly the weight of a physical grain. [[Image:Apothecaries weights 1800.png|thumb|300px|Map showing examples of the weight of 1 apothecaries' ounce in grammes around 1800, before metrication and the Prussian weight reform. The dashed lines indicate three different ways to subdivide the ounce.]] It is most convenient to compare the various local weight standards by the metric weights of their ounces. The actual mass of an ounce varied by ±17% (5 g) around the typical value of 30 g. The table only shows approximate values for the most important standards; even the same nominal standard could vary slightly between one city and its neighbour. The range from 25 g to 31 g is filled with numerous variants, especially the Italian range up to 28 g. But there is a relatively large gap between the troy ounces of 31 g and the Habsburg ounce of 35 g. The latter is the product of an 18th-century weight reform. Even in Turkey a system of weights similar to the European apothecaries' system was used for the same purpose. For medical purposes the tcheky (approx. 320 g) was divided in 100 drachms, and the drachm in (16 killos or) 64 grains.{{cite book | last=Beasley | first=Henry | title=The Druggist's general receipt book | location=London| year=1850 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DHYFAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA396 | page=396 }}{{cite book | location=Leipzig | title=Vollständiges Taschenbuch der Münz-, Maass- und Gewichtsverhältnisse | last=Noback | first=C. |author2=Noback, F. | year=1851 }} [https://books.google.com/books?id=GIMBAAAAQAAJ Volume 1] and [https://books.google.com/books?id=OYMBAAAAQAAJ Volume 2]. This is close to the classical Greek weight system, where a ''mina'' (corresponding roughly to a Roman ''libra'') was also divided into 100 drachms."The Greek weights, mentioned by Roman authors, are chiefly the ''talent'', divided into 60 ''minæ'', and the ''mina'' into 100 ''drachmæ.'' The ''mina'' was nearly equal to the Roman ''libra.''" {{cite book | last=Adam | first=Alexander |author2=James Boyd |author3=Lorenzo L. da Ponte | title=Roman Antiquities: Or an Account of the Manners and Customs of the Romans | edition=8th | location=New York | year=1842 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MP0LAAAAYAAJ&pg=PT376 }} With the beginning of metrication, some countries standardized their apothecaries' pound to an easily remembered multiple of the French [[gram]]me."Bayern [...] hat schon im Jahre 1811 nicht nur sein Civilgewicht in eine sehr zweckmäßige Übereinstimmung mit dem französischen Grammengewicht gebracht, sondern auch sein Medicinalgewicht genau nach dem neu eingeführten Civilgericht reguliert [...], wonach das Medicinalpfund (= 360 Grammes) sich zu dem Civilpfunde (= 560 Grammes) [...] wie 9:14 verhält [...]." "[...] ob es nicht besser wäre, das Medicinalgewicht nach diesem zu reguliren und das Apothekerpfund auf genau drei Viertheile des Zollpfunds festzustellen?" {{cite journal | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CJIDAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA715#PPA713,M1 | last=Seeger | title=Vorschlag zu Abänderung unseres gegenwärtigen bestehenden und zu Einführung eines gemeinsamen teutschen Medicinalgewichts | pages=713–724 | journal=Vereinigte deutsche Zeitschrift für die Staatsarzneikunde | year=1847 }} E.g. in the Netherlands the Dutch troy pound of 369.1 g was standardized in 1820 to 375.000 g, to match a similar reform in France. The British troy pound retained its value of 373.202 g until in 2000 it was legally defined in metric terms, as 373.2417216 g.Schedule 1 of [http://www.statutelaw.gov.uk/legResults.aspx?LegType=All+Legislation&title=weights+and+measures+act&Year=1985&searchEnacted=0&extentMatchOnly=0&confersPower=0&blanketAmendment=0&TYPE=QS&NavFrom=0&activeTextDocId=2191980&PageNumber=1&SortAlpha=0 Weight and Measurements Act 1985], as amended in 2000 by the Units of Measurement Regulations 1994. (At this time its use was already illegal for all purposes except trading precious metals.) ===Basic variants=== In the [[Romance language|Romance]] speaking part of Europe the scruple was divided in 24 grains, in the rest of Europe in 20 grains. Notable exceptions were Venice and Sicily, where the scruple was also divided in 20 grains.{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rWcOAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA94 | pages=94–96 | last=Phoebus | first=P. | title=Handbuch der Arzneiverordnungslehre | year=1836 | location=Berlin | volume=Vol. I}} {| align="center" | {|class="wikitable" |+ Non-Romance variant ! ''Libra'' !! ''Uncia'' !! ''Drachma'' !! ''Scrupulum'' !! ''Grana'' |- align="right" | 1 ''Lb.'' || 12 ''Unc.'' || 96 ''Dr.'' || 288 ''Scr.'' || 5,760 ''Gr.'' |- align="right" | || 1 ''Unc.'' || 8 ''Dr.'' || 24 ''Scr.'' || 480 ''Gr.'' |- align="right" | || || 1 ''Dr.'' || 3 ''Scr.'' || 60 ''Gr.'' |- align="right" | || || || 1 ''Scr.'' || 20 ''Gr.'' |- align="center" ! 360 g || 30 g || 4 g || 1.3 g || 60 mg |} | {|class="wikitable" |+ Romance variant ! ''Libra'' !! ''Uncia'' !! ''Drachma'' !! ''Scrupulum'' !! ''Grana'' |- align="right" | 1 ''Lb.'' || 12 ''Unc.'' || 96 ''Dr.'' || 288 ''Scr.'' || 6,912 ''Gr.'' |- align="right" | || 1 ''Unc.'' || 8 ''Dr.'' || 24 ''Scr.'' || 576 ''Gr.'' |- align="right" | || || 1 ''Dr.'' || 3 ''Scr.'' || 72 ''Gr.'' |- align="right" | || || || 1 ''Scr.'' || 24 ''Gr.'' |- align="center" ! 360 g || 30 g || 4 g || 1.3 g || 50 mg |} |} The Sicilian apothecaries' ounce was divided in 10 drachms. Since the scruple was divided in only 20 grains, like in the northern countries, an ounce consisted of 600 grains. This was not too different from the situation in most of the other mediterranean countries, where an ounce consisted of 576 grains. In France, at some stage the apothecaries' pound of 12 ounces was replaced by the larger civil pound of 16 ounces. The subdivisions of the apothecaries' ounce were the same as in the other Romance countries, however, and were different from the subdivisions of the otherwise identical civil ounce. ==Origins== ===Roman weight system=== {|class="wikitable" align="right" |+Roman weights ! ''libra'' !! ''uncia'' !! ''drachma''The obolus and the (originally Greek) drachma were later additions to the Roman weight system. [https://books.google.com/books?id=jX5BAAAAcAAJ&pg=RA3-PA829&ei=oAevTJXEBsrMswaAwZ3YDQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ved=0CDEQ6AEwAQ] !! ''scrupulum'' !! ''obolus'' !! ''siliqua'' !! ''chalcus'' |- align="right" | 1 pound || 12 ounces || 96 drachms || 288 scruples || 576 oboli || 1,728 siliquas || 4,608 chalci |- align="right" | ||1 ounce || 8 drachms || 24 scruples || 48 oboli || 144 siliquas || 384 chalci |- align="right" | || ||1 drachm  || 3 scruples || 6 oboli || 18 siliquas || 48 chalci |- align="right" | || || ||1 scruple || 2 oboli || 6 siliquas || 16 chalci |- ! 327 g !! 27.3 g !! 3.41 g !! 1.14 g !! 568 mg !! 189 mg !! 71 mg |} {{See also|Ancient Roman units of measurement}} The basic apothecaries' system consists of the units pound, ounce and scruple from the classical Roman weight system, together with the originally Greek drachm and a new subdivision of the scruple into either 20 ("barley") or 24 ("wheat") grains ({{lang-la|grana}}). In some countries other units of the original system remained in use, for example in Spain the ''obolo'' and ''siliqua''. In some cases the apothecaries' and civil weight systems had the same ounces ("an ounce is an ounce"), but the civil pound consisted of 16 ounces. ''Siliqua'' is Latin for the seed of the [[carob]] tree. Many attempts were made to reconstruct the exact mass of the Roman pound. One method for doing this consists in weighing old coins; another uses the fact that Roman weight units were derived from Roman units of length similarly to the way the kilogramme was originally derived from the metre, i.e. by weighing a known volume of water. Nowadays the Roman pound is often given as 327.45 g, but one should keep in mind that (apart from the other uncertainties that come with such a reconstruction) the Roman weight standard is unlikely to have remained constant to such a precision over the centuries, and that the provinces often had somewhat inexact copies of the standard. The weight and subdivision of the pound in the [[Holy Roman Empire]] was reformed by [[Charlemagne]], but in the [[Byzantine Empire]] it remained essentially the same. Since Byzantine coins circulated up to [[Scandinavia]], the old Roman standard continued to be influential through the Middle Ages. ===Weight system of Salerno=== {|class="wikitable" align="right" |+Doctors of SalernoThe last row is only to give a quick orientation and for comparison with other tables. It is based on an ounce of 30 g. ! ''Libra'' || ''Uncia'' || ''Drachma'' || ''Scrupulum'' || ''Granum'' |- align="right" | 1 ''Lb.'' || 12 ''Unc.'' || 108 ''Dr.'' || 324 ''Scr.'' || 6480 ''Gr.'' |- align="right" | || 1 ''Unc.'' || 9 ''Dr.'' || 27 ''Scr.'' || 540 ''Gr.'' |- align="right" | || || 1 ''Dr.'' || 3 ''Scr.'' || 60 ''Gr.'' |- align="right" | || || || 1 ''Scr.'' || 20 ''Gr.'' |- align="right" ! 360 g|| 30 g || 3.3 g || 1.1 g || 56 mg |} The history of mediaeval medicine started roughly around the year 1000 with the [[Schola Medica Salernitana|school of medicine in Salerno]], which combined elements of Latin, Greek, Arabic and Jewish medicine. [[Galen]] and [[Pedanius Dioscorides|Dioscorides]] (who had used the Graeco-Roman weight system) were among the most important authorities, but also Arabic physicians, whose works were systematically translated into Latin. According to ''De ponderibus et mensuris'', a famous 13th century text that exists in numerous variations and is often ascribed to [[Dino di Garbo]], the system of weights used in Salerno was different from the systems used in Padua and Bologna. As can be seen from the table, it was also different from the Roman weight system used by Galenus and Dioscorides and from all modern apothecaries' systems: The ounce was divided into 9 drachms, rather than 8 drachms. Centuries later, the region around [[Salerno]] was the only exception to the rule that (except for skipping units that had regionally fallen out of use) the apothecaries' ounce was subdivided down to the scruple in exactly the same way as in the Roman system: It divided the ounce into 10 drachms. ==Romance countries== While there will naturally have been some changes throughout the centuries, this section only tries to give a general overview over the situation that was recorded in detail in numerous 19th century merchants' handbooks. {|class="wikitable" align="left" style="margin:0 1em 0 0" |+ Some Romance apothecaries' weight standards in the 19th century ! 1 pound || 1 ounce || state or city |- | 301.2 g || 25.1 g || [[Venice]]Loehmann, ''Tafeln der Medicinal- und Apothekergewichte aller Länder und freier Städte in Europa etc.'', Leipzig 1832. (Alternative title: ''Tafeln zur Verwandlung des Längen- und Hohl-Maßes, sowie des Gewichts usw. aller Hauptländer Europas''.) Cited after {{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rWcOAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA91 | last=Phoebus | first=P. | title=Handbuch der Arzneiverordnungslehre | year=1836 | location=Berlin | volume=Vol. I | page=§ 40}}{{cite book | last=Hager | first=Hermann | authorlink = Hermann Hager | year=1861 | title=Medicamenta homoeopathica et isopathica omnia | location=Lesnae | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZhQ6AAAAMAAJ&pg=PA20#PPA18,M1 }} |- | 320.8 g
|| 26.7 g
|| [[Kingdom of the Two Sicilies]]Weights and measures of the mainland part of this kingdom, after uniformization in 1840.
(1816–1861){{cite book | last=Weinberger | first=Rudolf | title=Arznei-Verordnungslehre und vollständiges Recept-Taschenbuch nach der neuesten österr. Pharmakopöe | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gQMAAAAAQAAJ&printsec=frontcover#PPA11,M1 | location=Wien | year=1857 }} |- | 325.7 g || 27.1 g|| [[Bologna]] |- | 326.8 g || 27.2 g|| [[Milan]] (–1815) |- | 328.0 g || 27.3 g|| [[Parma]] |- | 332.0 g || 27.7 g|| [[Sardinia]] |- | 334.5 g || 27.9 g|| [[Duchy of Lucca]] (1815–1847) |- | 339.2 g || 28.3 g|| [[Rome]] |- | 339.5 g || 28.3 g|| [[Florence]] |- | 339.5 g || 28.3 g|| [[Grand Duchy of Tuscany]]
